He cites internal "Code Red" alerts, declining ChatGPT traffic, massive quarterly losses of $12 billion, and unsustainable costs for tools like Sora. Key departures and Elon Musk's lawsuit further highlight significant internal turmoil and financial strain.

OpenAI's Master Plan for India

Read George Noble’s full note on OpenAI

OPENAI IS FALLING APART IN REAL TIME

I've watched companies implode for decades.

This one has all the warning signs.

OpenAI declared "Code Red" in December.

Altman sent an internal memo telling employees to drop everything because Google's Gemini 3 is eating their lunch. Salesforce CEO Marc Benioff publicly ditched ChatGPT for Gemini after using it for two hours.

ChatGPT traffic fell in November. Second month-over-month decline of 2025.

Meanwhile Gemini jumped to 650 million monthly active users.

The company that was supposed to build AGI can't keep its chatbot competitive.

But the real story is the money...

OpenAI lost $12 BILLION in a single quarter according to Microsoft's own fiscal disclosures.

Deutsche Bank estimates $143 billion in cumulative negative cash flow before the company turns profitable.

Their analysts put it bluntly: "No startup in history has operated with losses on anything approaching this scale."

They're burning $15 million per day on Sora alone.

$5 billion annually to generate copyright-infringing memes.

Even Sora's lead engineer admitted the "economics are currently completely unsustainable."

Here's the big math problem nobody wants to discuss:

It's going to cost 5x the energy and money to make these models 2x better.

The low-hanging fruit is gone.

Every incremental improvement now requires exponentially more compute, more data centers, more power.

Reports suggest OpenAI's large training runs in 2025 failed to produce models better than prior versions.

GPT-5 launched to widespread disappointment. Users called it "underwhelming" and "horrible." OpenAI had to restore GPT-4o within 24 hours because users preferred the old model.

Altman had promised GPT-5 would make GPT-4 feel "mildly embarrassing." Instead, users complained it was worse at basic math and geography.

They've released GPT-5.1, GPT-5.2 since.

Same complaints each time: too corporate, too safe, robotic, boring.

The talent exodus makes this even worse:

CTO Mira Murati. Gone.

Chief Research Officer Bob McGrew. Gone.

Chief Scientist Ilya Sutskever. Gone.

President Greg Brockman. Gone.

Half the AI safety team departed. Multiple executives reportedly cited "psychological abuse" under Altman's leadership.

And now Elon Musk is suing for up to $134 billion.

A federal judge just ruled the case goes to jury trial in April. There's "plenty of evidence" that OpenAI's leaders promised to maintain the nonprofit structure that Musk funded.

Musk provided $38 million in early funding based on those assurances. Now he wants his share of the $500 billion valuation.

OpenAI called it "harassment." But the judge disagreed.

Here's what I think happens next:

The AI hype cycle is peaking.

The diminishing returns are becoming impossible to hide.

Competitors are catching up.

The lawsuits are piling up.

OpenAI needs to generate $200 billion in annual revenue by 2030 to justify their projections.

That's 15x growth in five years while costs keep exploding.

Even Sam Altman admitted investors are "overexcited" about AI.

His exact words: "Someone is going to lose a phenomenal amount of money."

If I were running an AI startup with good traction right now, I'd be looking for an exit.

Sell into the hype before the music stops.

My positioning:

I'm not touching OpenAI-adjacent plays at these valuations. The risk profile is astronomical.

If you're exposed to the Magnificent 7 through AI infrastructure bets, consider trimming. The gap between promised revolution and delivered reality has never been wider.

The smart money is rotating into sectors where valuations actually reflect fundamentals.

Small and mid-caps are trading near decade lows relative to Big Tech while earnings growth is only marginally lower.

Markets can price risk. But they can't price chaos.

And OpenAI is chaos dressed up in a $500 billion valuation.





Veteran investor George Noble has issued a stark warning about OpenAI , arguing the AI darling is "falling apart in real time" despite its eye-watering $500 billion valuation.In a scathing analysis on X, Noble highlighted what he calls unmistakable signs of trouble. The biggest red flag? OpenAI's internal "Code Red" memo in December, where Sam Altman reportedly told employees to drop everything as Google's Gemini eats into ChatGPT's dominance. The threat isn't hypothetical—ChatGPT traffic has dropped for two straight months while Gemini exploded to 650 million monthly users.The financial bleeding is worse. Noble points to Microsoft disclosures showing OpenAI burned through $12 billion in a single quarter. Deutsche Bank projects the company will rack up $143 billion in cumulative losses before seeing profit. OpenAI's video tool Sora alone costs $15 million daily to run, with even its own lead engineer admitting the economics are "completely unsustainable."Then there's the talent exodus. CTO Mira Murati, Chief Scientist Ilya Sutskever, and half the AI safety team have all walked out the door. Meanwhile, GPT-5 flopped so badly that OpenAI had to restore GPT-4 within 24 hours after users revolted.Now Elon Musk's $134 billion lawsuit heads to trial in April, with a federal judge finding solid evidence OpenAI broke promises about staying nonprofit.Noble's bottom line: the AI hype is peaking just as reality catches up, and OpenAI needs to grow revenue 15x in five years while costs spiral out of control.
Article Summary: Veteran investor George Noble warns OpenAI is "falling apart" despite its $500 billion valuation. He cites internal "Code Red" alerts, declining ChatGPT traffic, massive quarterly losses of $12 billion. Key departures and Elon Musk's lawsuit further highlight significant internal turmoil.

Article Title: Meta's $20 billion acquisitions of Instagram and WhatsApp back under fire as US government appeals loss
Article Text:
The Federal Trade Commission is appealing a ruling that dismissed its monopoly case against Meta, aiming to force the tech giant to divest Instagram and WhatsApp. A judge previously found Meta did not hold an illegal monopoly, citing the rise of TikTok and YouTube.

Trump-Era case continues despite Zuckerberg 's courtship

What's actually at stake for Meta





The Federal Trade Commission is taking another swing at Meta, filing an appeal Tuesday to challenge a November ruling that cleared the tech giant of monopoly charges. The move keeps alive the government's years-long effort to potentially force Meta to divest Instagram and WhatsApp—acquisitions made over a decade ago for $1 billion and $19 billion respectively.US District Judge James Boasberg had sided with Meta last year, concluding the company doesn't hold an illegal monopoly in personal social networking. His reasoning? The explosive growth of TikTok and YouTube fundamentally reshaped the competitive landscape, undercutting the FTC's arguments about Meta's market dominance.The appeal adds an awkward political dimension for Mark Zuckerberg , who spent much of 2025 attempting to repair his relationship with Donald Trump. Meta donated $1 million to Trump's inauguration fund and paid $25 million to settle lawsuits over the president's suspended Facebook and Instagram accounts. Despite these overtures, the FTC—now operating under Trump's second term—remains committed to the case."Meta violated our antitrust laws when it acquired Instagram and WhatsApp ," FTC spokesperson Joe Simonson said, emphasizing that "American consumers have suffered from Meta's monopoly."The agency's Bureau of Competition Director Daniel Guarnera framed the appeal as protecting fair competition, arguing Meta maintained dominance "not through legitimate competition, but by buying its most significant competitive threats."If the FTC succeeds on appeal, Meta could face forced restructuring or divestment of its prized acquisitions. The original 2020 lawsuit alleged Meta identified Instagram and WhatsApp as nascent threats and purchased them specifically to eliminate competition—a strategy the government claims allowed Meta to degrade service quality while loading up on ads without fear of users fleeing to alternatives.Meta's response has been measured. Spokesperson Andy Stone simply reiterated that the district court decision was "correct" and that Meta "will remain focused on innovating and investing in America"—echoing Trump-friendly talking points about domestic job creation even as the legal battle intensifies.
Article Summary: The Federal Trade Commission is appealing a ruling that dismissed its monopoly case against Meta. A judge previously found Meta did not hold an illegal monopoly, citing the rise of TikTok and YouTube. If the FTC succeeds on appeal, Meta could face forced restructuring or divestment of its prized acquisitions.

Article Title: Netflix to revamp its app to boost daily engagement; Takes on TikTok, Instagram and YouTube
Article Text:
What is changing in the Netflix app



The engagement challenge







Netflix is preparing for bringing a redesign of its app as the streaming giant is looking to compete directly with social media platforms for daily user engagement. As reported by TechCrunch, the redesign of the Netflix aims to make the app feel less static library of shows and more like a dynamic, interactive hub. While Netflix remains the world’s largest subscription streaming service, it faces growing competition not just from rival streamers but from social media platforms like TikTok, Instagram, and YouTube, which dominate daily attention spans.As per the report, the upcoming redesign of the Netflix app is said to include a personalised feed which will highlight the trending clips, recommendations and interactive prompts. The app is also expected to showcase short-form video previews which will be designed to mimic content style of TikTok. The Netflix app is also tipped to incorporated some interactive features such as polls, quizzes and community discussions related to shows and movies. The app will also focus on daily discovery and will also encourage users to explore beyond their usual watchlist.The challenge faced by Netflix is clear, while users may binge-watch series, they don’t necessarily open the app every day.Social platforms, by contrast, thrive on habitual engagement. By redesigning its app, Netflix hopes to close this gap and position itself as a platform where users spend time even when they’re not watching full episodes or films.The principle of daily engagement plays a crucial role in long-term strategy of Netflix. The frequent app visits could lead to increase retention rate among subscribers. It will also help in boosting advertising opportunities and will also help Netflix in strengthening attention share in an increasingly crowded digital landscape.
Article Summary: Netflix is preparing for bringing a redesign of its app as the streaming giant is looking to compete directly with social media platforms for daily user engagement. The redesign of the Netflix aims to make the app feel less static library of shows and more like a dynamic, interactive hub.

Article Title: Vodafone Idea rolls out 5G services in all 14 districts of Kerala; plans start at Rs 299
Article Text: Vodafone Idea (Vi) has expanded its 5G services to all 14 districts of Kerala. As announced by the company, Vi 5G is now available statewide. As an introductory offer, Vi is offering the most affordable 5G plan in the industry for Kerala users, with 5G packs starting at Rs 299. The telco said that it will systematically continue to expand 5G coverage to other regions in the State.With statewide coverage now live, Vi 5G is available in prime cities in all 14 districts, including Alapuzha, Kannur, Kalamassery, Kasaragod, Kalpeta, Kochi, Kollam, Kottayam, Kozhikode, Manjeri-Malappuram, Palakkad, Pathanamthitta, Tirur, Thrissur, Thodupzha, Thiruvananthapuram and Wayanad.Speaking on the statewide 5G rollout, George Mathew V. Cluster Business Head- Kerala, Vodafone Idea said, “We are happy to announce that Vi 5G is now available in every district in Kerala. In the second half of 2025, we accelerated 5G deployments across the state with advanced, energy-efficient infrastructure and AI-powered Self-Organizing Networks (SON) to automatically optimize network performance and deliver high-speed, reliable connectivity. With the enhanced network, we can confidently say that Vi 5G provides a future-ready experience built on high-performance connectivity.”As announced by the company, Vi has also strengthened its 4G network in Kerala. From September 2024 to September 2025, the telecom operator deployed over 3500 new 4G sites across 900 MHz, 1800 MHz and 2100 MHz spectrum bands, enhancing both indoor and outdoor network performance throughout the state.“Vi plans to add more sites in the coming months to further augment network capacity and bandwidth, reinforcing its commitment to delivering reliable, high-quality connectivity across urban and rural markets,” the telco said.
Article Summary: Vodafone Idea (Vi) has expanded its 5G services to all 14 districts of Kerala. As an introductory offer, Vi is offering the most affordable 5G plan in the industry for Kerala users. The telco said that it will systematically continue to expand 5G coverage to other regions in the State.

If ChatGPT can successfully integrate ads that are helpful rather than intrusive, it could siphon off valuable commercial queries that traditionally go to Google,”

ChatGPT maker OpenAI is expected to generate $25 billion in annual advertising revenue by 2030. According to predictions made by tech analysts, the expected increase in the AI startup’s ad revenue may potentially pose a threat to Google 's dominance in the digital ad market. Evercore ISI analyst Mark Mahaney has claimed that OpenAI may reach that level of annual ad revenue by 2030 if it executes well on rolling out this new business. In a note to investors (seen by Business Insider), Mahaney wrote: “A path to generating several billion dollars in ad revenue in 2026, going to $25B+ by 2030, seems reasonable.”However, it's important to note that this estimate is based on the likely scale of ChatGPT by that time, the proven monetisation of high-intent performance marketing platforms and the current size of this market, the analyst added. India To Join Pax Silica As US Signals New Tech Trust Despite Trade Tensions And Tariff Disputes

What is Trump administration’s new trade policy with China

Amodei previously said allowing Nvidia chip sales to China is ‘Mortgaging our future’





Anthropic CEO Dario Amodei has once again questioned the Trump administration’s trade policy, slamming the recent approval of selling Nvidia’s H200 artificial intelligence (AI) chip sales to China. He called it a blunder with “incredible national security implications”.“I think this is crazy. It’s a bit like selling nuclear weapons to North Korea. It would be a big mistake to ship these chips,” Amodei said at Bloomberg at the World Economic Forum.Anthropic CEO’s warning comes weeks after President Donald Trump eased the bans on advanced AI chip exports, and approved the sale of AI chips to Beijing. This policy shift is a major victory for Nvidia, which has argued that continued bans merely incentivise China to develop its own domestic alternatives. The chipmaker also claimed that China making their own chips will potentially lock American firms out of the world’s second-largest economy permanently.Under the new guidelines, Nvidia’s H200 will become the most advanced AI chip legally available to Chinese customers. However, multiple reports claim that China has asked its customs officials that Nvidia’s high-end chips are not allowed in the mainland.Meanwhile, AMD is reportedly seeking similar clearance for MI325X to compete in the Chinese market.It is to be noted that Nvidia’s Blackwell and upcoming Vera Rubin architectures will remain strictly restricted for US and allied use.In September, Amodei’s alarmed the US government that American dominance in semiconductor technology is the nation's final strategic leverage over China and that the AI chip embargo was the one area where Washington held a decisive advantage.“It is mortgaging our future as a country to sell these chips to China,” Amodei warned, describing the policy shift as “the single most disastrous national security decision made in this term.”“This could control the fate of nations. This could control the future of freedom and democracy,” Amodei noted during the Axios AI+ DC Summit.
